anns.exact: ABSTRACT Lasalocid, a representative polyether ionophore, has been successfully applied in veterinary medicine and animal husbandry and also displays promising potential for cancer therapy.

anns.exact: Here, we identified two conserved (lodR2 and lodR3) and one variable (lodR1, found only in Streptomyces sp. strain FXJ1.172) putative regulatory genes through a comparison of the lasalocid biosynthetic gene cluster (lod) from Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 with those (las and lsd) from Streptomyces lasalocidi.

tags.postfix: biosynthetic gene cluster (lod) from Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 with those (las and lsd) from Streptomyces lasalocidi.

anns.exact: Here, we characterize the roles of regulatory genes in lasalocid biosynthetic gene clusters of two distinct Streptomyces species and identify a conserved repressor-activator system, LodR2–LodE, which could sense changes in the concentration of lasalocid and coordinate its biosynthesis with self-resistance.

tags.name: lasalocid
tags.prefix: Here, we characterize the roles of regulatory genes in
tags.postfix: biosynthetic gene clusters of two distinct Streptomyces species and identify a conserved repressor-activator system, LodR2–LodE, which could sense changes in the concentration of lasalocid and coordinate its biosynthesis with self-resistance.

anns.exact: Furthermore, in parallel, we verify that the regulatory system identified in a new Streptomyces isolate is valid in the industrial lasalocid producer and thus applicable for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.exact: Lasalocid (4), one of the seven currently marketed carboxylic polyether ionophores, has been validated as a classical anticoccidial drug for poultry and a growth promoter in ruminants (5, 6).

tags.name: Lasalocid
tags.postfix: (4), one of the seven currently marketed carboxylic polyether ionophores, has been validated as a classical anticoccidial drug for poultry and a growth promoter in ruminants (5, 6).

anns.exact: Lasalocid selectively inhibits intracellular sporozoites while remaining relatively noninjurious to the host cell, and it has biased antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive bacteria, whereas most Gram-negative strains are still refractory (7).

tags.name: Lasalocid
tags.postfix: selectively inhibits intracellular sporozoites while remaining relatively noninjurious to the host cell, and it has biased antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive bacteria, whereas most Gram-negative strains are still refractory (7).

anns.exact: Moreover, lasalocid and its synthetic analogs have shown high antiproliferative activity against cancer cell lines and, simultaneously, lower cytotoxicity toward nontumor cells than cisplatin, which hints at their potential to be developed as candidates for cancer treatment (2, 3, 9, 10).

anns.exact: Unlike nig and sln, the BGCs of monensin (mon) and nanchangmycin (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. These regulators form complex coregulatory cascades governing the biosynthesis of monensin and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

anns.exact: To verify the role of these genes in lasalocid biosynthesis, the corresponding disruption mutants (Δlas2, Δlas3, and Δlas4) were constructed from the S. lasalocidi ATCC 31180T wild type (31180-WT).

tags.name: lasalocid
tags.prefix: To verify the role of these genes in
tags.postfix: biosynthesis, the corresponding disruption mutants (Δlas2, Δlas3, and Δlas4) were constructed from the S. lasalocidi ATCC 31180T wild type (31180-WT).

anns.exact: Compared to that of 31180-WT, the lasalocid yield of the Δlas2 mutant was greatly reduced (from 33.8 to 4.7 mg/L), and that of the Δlas3 mutant was increased (from 33.8 to 112.5 mg/L), while lasalocid was no longer detected in the Δlas4 mutant (Fig. 7A).

tags.name: lasalocid
tags.prefix: Compared to that of 31180-WT, the
tags.postfix: yield of the Δlas2 mutant was greatly reduced (from 33.8 to 4.7 mg/L), and that of the Δlas3 mutant was increased (from 33.8 to 112.5 mg/L), while lasalocid was no longer detected in the Δlas4 mutant (Fig. 7A).

anns.exact: As a result, both the ΔlodR3 mutant cross-complemented with las4 and the Δlas4 mutant cross-complemented with lodR3 could restore lasalocid production to the level of the WT strains (Fig. 7B).

tags.name: lasalocid
tags.prefix: As a result, both the ΔlodR3 mutant cross-complemented with las4 and the Δlas4 mutant cross-complemented with lodR3 could restore
tags.postfix: production to the level of the WT strains (Fig. 7B).

anns.exact: All of these results are consistent with those for Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, indicating a conserved regulatory mechanism of lasalocid biosynthesis in the two species.

anns.exact: Based on the above-described regulatory studies, high-yield lasalocid-producing strains were constructed by overexpressing las4 in the Δlas3 mutant via a multicopy vector, pKC1139::PkasO*las4, or a single-site integrative vector, pSET152::PkasO*las4.

tags.name: lasalocid-producing
tags.prefix: Based on the above-described regulatory studies, high-yield
tags.postfix: strains were constructed by overexpressing las4 in the Δlas3 mutant via a multicopy vector, pKC1139::PkasO*las4, or a single-site integrative vector, pSET152::PkasO*las4.

anns.exact: The resultant mutants, Δlas3-1139-las4OE and Δlas3-152-las4OE, enhanced their lasalocid yields by 5.1 and 6.8 times, respectively, compared to 31180-WT (Fig. 7A).

tags.name: lasalocid
tags.prefix: The resultant mutants, Δlas3-1139-las4OE and Δlas3-152-las4OE, enhanced their
tags.postfix: yields by 5.1 and 6.8 times, respectively, compared to 31180-WT (Fig. 7A).

anns.exact: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene las3 and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with lasalocid production of up to 230 mg/L. S. lasalocidi strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.exact: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene las3 and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with lasalocid production of up to 230 mg/L. S. lasalocidi strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.exact: In this study, we demonstrate that lasalocid specifically binds to the MarR family transcription repressor LodR2 and causes its dissociation from the promoter region of lodR2–lodE (Fig. 5B), thus activating the transcription of lodE. This finding coincides with the defining feature of MarR family regulators: they normally respond to specific ligands, resulting in attenuated DNA-binding activity and often the derepression of target gene transcription (38).

anns.exact: Recently, a polyether antibiotic, calcimycin, has also been proven to inhibit the DNA-binding activity of its cognate CSR CalR3, which subsequently initiates the expression of the calcimycin transporter-encoding gene calT (39).

anns.exact: The transporter LodE is also crucial for lasalocid biosynthesis because disruption of lodE results in reduced lasalocid production and an increased ratio of intracellular/extracellular lasalocid concentrations.

anns.exact: It is noteworthy that the residual production of lasalocid in the ΔlodE mutant implies the existence of other efflux systems in the producer strain, as seen in the salinomycin producer Streptomyces albus BK3-25 (40).

anns.exact: For lasalocid production, a suitable number of spores (~2.5 × 106) of Streptomyces sp. anns.exact: Unlike nig and sln, the BGCs of monensin (mon) and nanchangmycin (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. anns.exact: Unlike nig and sln, the BGCs of monensin (mon) and nanchangmycin (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. These regulators form complex coregulatory cascades governing the biosynthesis of monensin and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

anns.exact: Bioinformatics analysis revealed that the cluster contains 22 open reading frames (ORFs), designated lodA–lodT. In this study, to unravel the regulatory mechanism of lasalocid biosynthesis in different Streptomyces species, we first compared lod with the other two lasalocid gene clusters (las and lsd from S. lasalocidi strains).

anns.exact: Intriguingly, lod contains four exclusive ORFs: lodR1, encoding a TetR family regulator; lodA, encoding a protein with domains of unknown functions; lodB, encoding a monooxygenase; and lodC, encoding a 3-oxoacyl-ACP (acyl carrier protein) synthase that is much longer than its putative homologs encoded by orf09 in las and lsd3 in lsd (Table 1 and Fig. 1).

anns.exact: Based on the above-described regulatory studies, high-yield lasalocid-producing strains were constructed by overexpressing las4 in the Δlas3 mutant via a multicopy vector, pKC1139::PkasO*las4, or a single-site integrative vector, pSET152::PkasO*las4.

tags.name: las4
tags.prefix: Based on the above-described regulatory studies, high-yield lasalocid-producing strains were constructed by overexpressing
tags.postfix: in the Δlas3 mutant via a multicopy vector, pKC1139::PkasO*las4, or a single-site integrative vector, pSET152::PkasO*las4.

anns.exact: The resultant mutants, Δlas3-1139-las4OE and Δlas3-152-las4OE, enhanced their lasalocid yields by 5.1 and 6.8 times, respectively, compared to 31180-WT (Fig. 7A).

tags.name: las4OE
tags.prefix: The resultant mutants, Δlas3-1139-
tags.postfix: and Δlas3-152-las4OE, enhanced their lasalocid yields by 5.1 and 6.8 times, respectively, compared to 31180-WT (Fig. 7A).

anns.exact: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene las3 and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with lasalocid production of up to 230 mg/L. S. lasalocidi strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.exact: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene las3 and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with lasalocid production of up to 230 mg/L. S. lasalocidi strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.exact: Although we attributed the undisturbed lasalocid production in the mutant strain 31180-R1ABC to the inhibition of lodA–lodC expression by LodR1, we cannot exclude another possibility, that all of these genes are not well expressed in the heterologous host, and more details are needed to further check whether the repression of the expression of lodA–lodC by LodR1 is functionally conserved in S. lasalocidi.

anns.exact: In this study, we demonstrate that lasalocid specifically binds to the MarR family transcription repressor LodR2 and causes its dissociation from the promoter region of lodR2–lodE (Fig. 5B), thus activating the transcription of lodE. This finding coincides with the defining feature of MarR family regulators: they normally respond to specific ligands, resulting in attenuated DNA-binding activity and often the derepression of target gene transcription (38).

anns.exact: Here, we identified two conserved (lodR2 and lodR3) and one variable (lodR1, found only in Streptomyces sp. strain FXJ1.172) putative regulatory genes through a comparison of the lasalocid biosynthetic gene cluster (lod) from Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 with those (las and lsd) from Streptomyces lasalocidi.

anns.exact: Gene disruption experiments demonstrated that both lodR1 and lodR3 positively regulate lasalocid biosynthesis in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, while lodR2 plays a negative regulatory role.

anns.exact: Here, we characterize the roles of regulatory genes in lasalocid biosynthetic gene clusters of two distinct Streptomyces species and identify a conserved repressor-activator system, LodR2–LodE, which could sense changes in the concentration of lasalocid and coordinate its biosynthesis with self-resistance.

tags.name: Streptomyces
tags.prefix: Here, we characterize the roles of regulatory genes in lasalocid biosynthetic gene clusters of two distinct
tags.postfix: species and identify a conserved repressor-activator system, LodR2–LodE, which could sense changes in the concentration of lasalocid and coordinate its biosynthesis with self-resistance.

anns.exact: Furthermore, in parallel, we verify that the regulatory system identified in a new Streptomyces isolate is valid in the industrial lasalocid producer and thus applicable for the construction of high-yield strains.

tags.name: Streptomyces
tags.prefix: Furthermore, in parallel, we verify that the regulatory system identified in a new
tags.postfix: isolate is valid in the industrial lasalocid producer and thus applicable for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.exact: Unlike nig and sln, the BGCs of monensin (mon) and nanchangmycin (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. These regulators form complex coregulatory cascades governing the biosynthesis of monensin and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

anns.exact: Three genes of the lod cluster are proposed to play a regulatory role in lasalocid biosynthesis in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, including a variable gene (lodR1) and two conserved ones (lodR2 and lodR3).

tags.postfix: , including a variable gene (lodR1) and two conserved ones (lodR2 and lodR3).

anns.exact: To verify the functions of these genes, we constructed their mutants by disruptive in-frame deletions in the Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 wild type (FXJ1.172-WT) and designated them ΔlodR1, ΔlodR2, and ΔlodR3, respectively.

tags.postfix: wild type (FXJ1.172-WT) and designated them ΔlodR1, ΔlodR2, and ΔlodR3, respectively.

anns.exact: These results indicate that lodR1 and lodR3 positively regulate lasalocid biosynthesis in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, while lodR2 plays a negative regulatory role.

anns.exact: (D) HPLC analysis of lasalocid A production in the Streptomyces lasalocidi ATCC 31180T wild type (31180-WT) and its derivatives 31180-KABC and 31180-R1ABC after fermentation for 240 h. 31180-KABC contains plasmid pSET152 with locus lodA–C driven by PkasO*, and 31180-R1ABC contains plasmid pSET152 with locus lodR1–C. anns.exact: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene las3 and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with lasalocid production of up to 230 mg/L. S. lasalocidi strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.exact: Our results reveal that lasalocid biosynthesis in different Streptomyces species is controlled by one variable and two conserved regulatory systems, providing an understanding of the regulatory diversification and mechanism.

anns.exact: The distant phylogenetic relationship between Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 and S. lasalocidi (96.2% 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity and 81.7% genome-wide average nucleotide identity) (24) and their disparate soil origins, red soil in China (25) and park soil in the United States (34), respectively, both support the divergent-evolution hypothesis.

anns.exact: For lasalocid production, a suitable number of spores (~2.5 × 106) of Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172-WT, wild-type S. lasalocidi ATCC 31180T, or their mutants was inoculated into a 50-mL centrifuge tube containing 10 mL of liquid tryptic soy broth (TSB) (pancreatic digest of 1.7% casein and papaic digest of 0.3% soybean, 0.25% dextrose, 0.5% NaCl, and 0.25% K2HPO4 [pH 7.1 to 7.5]) and incubated on a rotary shaker at 220 rpm at 28°C for 48 h as a seed culture.
